12oz bottle  shared by BlackForestCO.  Batch 7777.  Pours black with reddish hues, small nonexistent head.  Aromas of cherry, lactose, chocolate and some coffee.  Flavor is sweet cherry, chocolate, and some coffee in the finish.  Palate is very nice, rich and mellow.  Thanks again Jake.

bottle at Ft Wayne locals tasting, courtesy of bdigi66, I think - Pours up very dark brown with a small tan head.  It smells of bourbon, cherries, and roast malt as one would expect.  The cherry flavor mixed in with that sweet roast malt is mild but definitely there.  The bourbon is well balanced, good without overpowering the other elements.  Its medium to full bodied and finishes slightly bitter.  Very nice.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of a trade with dkachur.  Pours black with a moderate brown head that completely disappears after the first sip and did not leave a single spot of lace.  Very pleasant aroma of vanilla, bourbon, malt, oak, and some alcohol vapors.  Although I am enjoying the aroma, I am not picking up any of the cherry.  The flavor is vanilla, bourbon and malt.  The cherry finally emerges in the aftertaste, along with some warming alcohol, and reminds me a bit of childrens cough syrup.  Fairly smooth at the finish.  Full bodied.  An enjoyable beer, but not outstanding.

Cask hand pumped by Larry himself at the JCBF09. Perfect Black with a tiny tan head and just hints of red on the edges. Nose is intense cherry with some woody smoky notes, the complexity in the flavor is slightly lacking in the taste. Taste is like Raspberry Eisbock levels of amazing decadence. Chocolate covered cherries, little to no carbonation though there is a little natural carb, but its just perfect for what feels like the ultimate desert beer. I had 3 pours of this, everyone who tried it instantly fell in love with it that I saw and it really became better and more complex with each sip. Wood, smoke, and even slight bit of sourness at the backend all make this far better than any other fruit beer stout I have ever had. Simply Amazing and big props to Larry for standing in the middle of the field and hand pumping this cask for everyone.

At the pub and then from a bottle and there was a consensus. I cannot understand how this is so popular while to me, this brewery produces at least two dozens more interesting brews. The pitch black pour with its medium tan head does not generate that evocative a smells. The balance immediately leans toward the name of the product, cherries and bourbon and the result provides lots of fruity acidity that more or less fits the roastiness. Pleasant smokiness if the finish does not quite catch up as the heavy fruitiness makes it feels awkward and juicy. Never clashing, but with every sip, it makes me wonder why I dont step over to change the content of my glass.

Pours black with some quickly fading brown head.  The nose is pretty balanced with bourbon, cherry, and chocolate.  The flavor is pretty well balanced as well, but theres an abrasive oak tannin finish that I didnt really care for.  Medium body with semi-sweet finish.  Tasty, but not great.

12oz bottle from lampeno420, thanks again Andrew!  Aroma has notes of bourbon, sour cherry, smoke, wood, chocolate, dried dark fruits and alcohol.  Smells 10x better than Bells cherry stout.  Black in the glass with a rusty tinge along the edges.  Average sized foamy brown head that mostly diminished and left virtually no lace.  Flavor is sweet and sour with a medium tart finish.  Palate is medium bodied and lively.  Really liked this one.  Nice blend of sour tartness and woody bourbon.  Very nice.

Bottle 12fl.oz.Clear dark black color with a average to large, frothy - creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, beige to light brown head. Aroma is heavy malty, roasted, chocolate, mjød (mead), cherry, wood, vanilla. Flavor is heavy sweet, moderate acidic and moderae to heavy bitter with a wood malt bitter dry dry finish. Body is medium, texture is oily - syrupy, carbonation is soft. [20081004]

Bottle thanks to golubj via some other person.  Aroma of cherry, chocolate, bourbon, vanilla, and a slight hint of roasted malt.  Flavor had a complex brew of flavors with alot of vanilla, caramel, cherries, bourbon and cocoa.  Something that came across as red winey as well.  Flavor is almost too rich to the point of being cloying.  Still, it was very nice in moderation.  Good stuff.

Bottle, thanks to someone.  Black pour, a brown ring of head.  Aroma is a lot of bourbon, wood, light vanilla, cocoa and cherry cordials.  Flavor is the same, but the cherry wine-like fruit is more pronounced.  Good woodiness and bourbon also, which is not too overbearing.  Nice brew.

Bottle from personal stash- last years batch. Pours thick, dark, reddish/brown, with a light reddish/brown head that is foamy but discipates quickly, leaving a small ring and light, intermittent lace. Nose is of vanilla, a little caramel, and a lot of sweet, red wine/cherries. The initial taste is moderately astringent and tangy with the wine/cherry, and semi-sweet chocolate following. The alcohol, as soft bourbon, is present and warming behind the above, bolder flavors. Nice stout variation for some quality sitting and sipping.

Pours a oily dark brown opaque color with a small fizzy brown head that dissipates completely. Nose of bourbon, vanilla, hints of nuts, touch of cherry. Initial taste of cherry, bourbon overlaying a syrupy vanilla and mollasses. Mid palate becomes slightly vinous with touches of cocoa. Finishing with good palate duration of alcohol warmth and bourbon. The rich sweet malt is some what shocking to the palate at first, but as you the sip further into this brew it becomes quite intriguing.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2008 # 1050.  Bottle courtesy of Todd.  Pours a black color with a medium light brown foamy head.  Aroma of bourbon, wood, vanilla, coconut and cherries.  Taste of buttery vanilla coconut, bourbon, cherries and wood.  Very interesting brew.  Tasty.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2009 In short: Bourbon Barrels, sweet cherries and stout clash with each other more than they work together.   A bad idea.
How: Bottle 12oz, consumed when about 4 months old.  From CharlesDarwin, thanks a lot buddy.
The look: Black body topped by a very small tan head
In long: Light-medium roastiness level.  Taste of concentrate cherry juice, some other red fruits, black liquorice and a whole lot of bourbon barrels.  Vanilla and more vanilla, the barrels here contributed way too much vanilla.  Syrupy limy body.  No hops presence.  This beer is what it says it is, bourbon barrels and cherry stout.  Cherry character is really sweet maraschino cherries and not fresh tart cherries and that doesnt work with the bourbon barrel at all.  Tonight I had my only two Bourbon Barrel Cherry Stouts (this one and the Central Waters) and while not the total mess that was the Central Waters this beer was less than convincing.  I now believe that Bourbon Barrels, Cherries and Stout are three elements that blend together as well as bananas, ketchup and maple syrup.

Courtesy of CharlesDarwin, thanks buddy, this was a special treat. Pours deep darkness with dark mocha to brown head. The aroma starts with mild bourbon that moves toward smooth oak, hints of roasty malts, faint alcohol heat and some dark ripe cherries riding around in the background (causing trouble, no doubt). The taste hits all at once with an array of notes of malty goodness, roasted malts and bourbon and then followed by sweet ripe cherries, chocolate, molasses and vanilla. This is just plain yummy.

My Bottom Line:
Anisey bourbon is emboldened by vinous cherries, as fruity tartness, chocolate and caramel attempt to coexist. This rich creation is the home for many voluble flavors, but I fear I do not see them as being as harmonious and pleasant as most here.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A ring of foam crowns the velvety black.
-Although there are a few crunchy biscuity notes, most of the flavors are expressed in the sweet realm of things.
-The body is as voluptuous as most of Bell’s big beers.
-The finish isnt too long, but that makes the beer much more drinkable.
-Alcohol hits quite seriously midway.
-The sequence of flavors is just bizarre to my tastes, although I admit I thought bourbon and cherries would work better together. My loss, I guess.

Bottle.

Bottle courtesy of miketd.  Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Smells of cherries, boozy bourbon, rich sweet malt, a hint of spice.  Tastes peppery and oaky with a nice accompaniment of cherries, oaky hints, vanilla and roasted malt.  Yet another home run from this brewer’s line of stouts and porters.

Courtesy of ibrew2or3.
Pours black, with brownish head.
Aroma, bourbon barrel and cherry, and possibly some vanilla.
Taste, plenty of chocolate malts to go about. This is couple with soem nice cherry notes, giving the beer some really well used bitterness.
Good balance, and for once the cherry is not too pronounced and leaves room for the rest to really come alive in this beer. You get everything from the chocolate - cherry - bourbon - vanilla etc all blended perfectly.

Bottle, once more, with thanks from nbutler11.  Smells great: thick sweet bourbon, vanilla-caramel, chocolate-covered cherries.  The flavor is more subdued than the un-aged version.  By that I mean that while the bourbon overlaps with both the cherry and stout elements, it enhances neither.  While it may not eliminate both (and my first instinct was to say so), it certainly competes with both, often to the point of interference.  But fattie cheers on a unique brew.

Bottle: (Thanks ygtbsm94!) Pours an opaque black with a deep brown dense thin head. The aroma has lots of bourbon and oak along with dark chocolate, roast, tart cherry notes mesh to make an interesting burnt marshmallow character. Substantial and creamy feel. The flavor is very interesting. Rich malt presence mingles with a tart cherry character and sweet bourbon. Some roasts comes through giving it a burnt marshmallow like deliciousness. Some residual toasted oak is apparent into the oaky roasted finish. A very unique and well integrated Stout. Balanced and complex.

Bottle fresh from a trade with Douglas88. Black with a thin dark brown head. Aroma of cherries starts with the pour. Scent from the glass is a cherry-chocolate liquere with hint of alcohol. A strong bitter quality gives the beer a tasty sour edge from start to finish. Swish the tongue and you get some of the Bourbon characteristics. Lighter in body than expected. Finishes more like a chocolate cherry wine than a beer.

Bottle courtesy of Ibrew2or3. Pours black with a one finger tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of bourbon, cherries, oak, vanilla, and a touch of roasted malt. Taste has tons of sour cherries, bourbon, oak, and vanilla. Medium full mouthfeel with a moderate amount of bitterness and slightly warm alcohol. Very good.

Bottle from KingpinIPA, thanks mike.  sweet smelling, hint of chocolate and cherries. Taste was all cherries at first with a aftertaste of bitter chocoalte and alcohol.  Mouthfeel was kinda thin with an oily film.  This is great beer, but must be drank as an after dinner beer for sure

Bottle thanks to John!  Timed this one perfectly and enjoyed with an apple crisp after dinner.  Big black pour with light tan head and perhaps a slightly pinkish tint?  Nose of candy corn, vanilla, toffee, caramel, bourbon, and bitter chocolate.  Cherries are almost absent on the nose, but there’s a tartness that you can tell is coming.  It hits right before the aftertaste, tingling the back and sides of your tongue.  Very sweet but complex beer with a great tingly full mouthfeel.  A nearly perfect dessert beer.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 Bottle, thanks northernbrews!  Rich aroma, cherry, bourbon, roast malts.  Pours black with a prominent coffee-brown head, spotty lace.  On the tongue, tart cherries blend perfectly with the roast malts to explode on the tongue.  Sweet bourbon, vanilla, and bitter oak complement the backbone nicely.  Finishes with coffee, chocolate, vanilla, a little bit of bitter melon.  Carmelly smooth on the palate, carbonation is subdued but prickly.  This is a nearly perfect beer.

Glad to see MrBunn liked it as I knew he would.....the only complaint I have about this beer is the fact that I left myself short changed with only one left in the fridge.(batch 7777) Wonderful flavor and aroma...almost wine-like...sweet and tart cherry flavor with said hints of vanilla, cream and chocolate....the bourbon flavor is just enough..not overpowering with the smokey oak in the background.
why I didnt buy more Ill never know.
Bottle. Sweet stout. Flavor of butterscotch (not good) and tart cherry (very good).  A little too sweet and too much buttery taste.

Bottle from the most excellent moejuck: pours a black very large bubbley espresso tan head. aroma is very vanilla and sweet, lots of cherry and decent chocolate, oak, plenty of cherry vannila cream.  flavour is awesome vry complex and long. starts very tart cherry and tons of vanilla then just fades into a great chocolate and finishes seconds after swalloing with roast. just a fantastic beer very well done.

Bottle with a special thanks to coyotehunter (Batch 7777, released Oct. 2008).  Pours a dark brown with a medium-sized reddish-tan head and aromas that hint at cherries, cream, vanilla and light chocolate.  Flavor is a wild mix of tart cherries, bourbon, peat, cream and chocolate, and damn is it tasty.  The tartness from the cherries was what caught me totally off guard.  Unlike its un-aged sister, the BA Cherry Stout is complex... or else the cherry flavors have died back to let some of the complexities shine through a little better.  Too bad this only comes out once in a blue moon and you have to hit the brewery jackpot to get some...
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: thanks mcbackus what an amazing flavor experience starts out with great cherry flavors that linger on the palate for quit some time before the wonderfull vanilla and chocolate flavors wash across the tongue. flavors that last and last and last.

12 fl oz bottle, courtesy of Papsoe. Pours pitch black with diminished tan head. Dense cherry aroma with roasted malt. Smooth vanilla note too. Dense malty flavoured with a acidic cherry flavour and light sourish citric note. Vanilla flavour to the quickly declining cherry base flavour. Goes into a smooth and more subdued cherry finish. Slight mead like. Stunning aroma, less impressive in the flavour.

Bottle thanks to mar.  I mean thanks, mar, really.  the beer was incredible.  Pours dark black, not much head.  Aroma was divine... vanilla, bourbon, chocolate, coffee icecream, cherry, a little wood.  Smelled something different with each sniff.  Flavor of dark coffee, cherry undertones... Wood and tart cherry finish emerge as well.  tastes like a really good cherry chocolate.  Smooth drinking and incredibly complex.

Bottle. Pretty sure pepsican shared this one with us. Thanks. Poured a murky opaque dark brown color. The head was a funky orange-ish brown color. Smelled of buttered toast, light butterscotch, subdued dark cherry, and a splash of booze. Kind of had a buttered popcorn aroma. Medium bodied and boozy with a light tart note. Vanilla, bourbon, buttered popcorn, and black cherry flavors mingled well together.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Courtesy of fiver29. Pours completely opaque black with a light brown head. Intriguing and intense bourbon aroma with some alcohol shining through. Medium body, the roasted malt accents are surprisingly subdued but the beer is dominated by a distinct sourness. The cherry notes turn up late but are strong and distinct and also add almond and coconut accents. No real bitterness but an acidic finish. Unique. 051008

Bottle. Very nice and distinct vanilla aroma. Fat cream and vanilla, hint of whiskey, some cherry. Black colour. Small stable brown head. Citric flavour, probably from the cherry. Plenty of vanilla and oak flavours. The cherry flavour starts in the sourness and ends with some citric fruitiness.

Black pour with a light brown head.  Smells like a new world pinot noir collided with a stout with a splash of bourbon in the mix.  Lots of cherries evident.  Tastes of sour cherries on the entry, stout on the mid-palate, then some more cherry tartness and smooth wood tannins on the finish with just a hint of bourbon.  The palate could be a bit thicker and richer ( I wrestled with giving it a 3 or a 4) but, all in all, a really nice, complex beer.

I really wanted to like this, particularly since it was a gift from a friend.  Aroma and flavor was almost of a chemical nature - like glue.  I love bourbon, cherries, and beer, but this mix just didn’t work.

12oz bottle via trade with drewbeerme, thanks Andrew. Poured very black with a fizzy tan head. Aroma smells like vanilla or butterscotch a little as well as cherries. Pretty good cherry flavor with a little woodiness in the backround, damn tasty beer.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: thanks mike.  pours a nice thick dark black with great head.  smells so boozy, with a bit of cherries.  the taste is actually pretty good, well balanced, not too much of anything.  definitely better than the regular cherry stout.

Pours very dark with a nice burnt orange head.  The aroma has a lot of vanilla, rich tart cherries, oak and just a touch of bourbon.  Medium / full body with a bit of biting carbonation, but overall smooth.  The flavor has a good blend of bourbon and stout with the bourbon not completely overtaking things.  The aroma traits are still in effect.  Good beer.

Sample at Wine and Cheese Place in St. Louis.  Thanks, Paul.
Lots of bourbon, vanilla, and oak in the aroma.  Chocolate is present, so is a touch of alcohol and cherries.  
Palate is a touch fizzy but quickly becomes creamy, almost viscous.  The only thing preventing this from being cloying, over-the-top chocolate is the presence of the vanilla-oak and tart cherry. 
Very nice.  Lingers, but does not intrude.

Bottle shared generously by sauceyhops at the Alesmith 07 Barrel-Aged Speedway release. Pitch black with brown bubbles. Thanks Gabe for bringing this one. The aroma of this is killer! Lots of bourbon and smoky wood with tones of espresso, prunes and cherry. Robust and sweet flavor, packed with blackened malt, more espresso and vanilla. The cherry juice adds a pleasing tartness to the bourbon and oak. Medium carbonation, soft mouth-feel and very drinkable. Great stuff.

12 oz bottle.  Dark brown with some tan froth.  Nose is bourbon, cherry preserves and coffee.  Juicy medium body with a light sparkle.  Taste like the nose.  Cherry is sweet enough to soften the bourbon bite but still a bit tart.  Coffee comes out in the finish with hints of chocolate.

Bottle @ home, from Secret Santa. Black and opague. Oaky, vinous aroma with cherrywine and hints of bourbon. Full bodied, malty sweet, slightly roasty but also velvety flavor with bourbon, oak, cherry, marzipan, vanilla, chocolate and warming alcohol. Soft, velvety but also an amazing complexity. World class beer, absolutely amazing, and a great gift from my Secret Santa.

Pours black with a small tan head.  Aroma is heavy butter,  cherry, oak,  and bourbon.  Flavor comes through with tart black cherry,  vanilla,  butter,  roasted malt,  butterscotch,  bourgon.  Finishes very smooth,  mild tartness is balanced with the nice buttery vanilla of the bourbon.  yum!

Thanks to Rustychiles. Pours just this side of jet black with a quickly dissipating chocolaty head. Smells first like massive diacetyl and oxidation. given some time and deeper sniffing reveals lots of bourbon, oak, and vanilla notes behind the diacetyl/butterscotch smell. Minor hints of cherry in there too. Taste is very roasty, a little cherry and vanilla, and beyond anything else butterscotch. Lots of alcohol as well. Would like to have seen more cherry and far less butterscotch.

12 oz bottle shared with toncatcher.  Another great smelling beer.  Super dark pour that I just smelled and smelled and smelled.  Aromas of cherry and wooden vanilla.   Finally tasted it and got some more cherry and vanilla.  Roasted malts in there of course.  Pretty darn yummy

Bottle at Sune’s (Thanks Bager). Black - brown head. High dumle, high caramel/chocolate candy, roasted, light burned, bourbon, vanilla, cherry, oak, wood, cookies, high sweetness, big smooth body. A bit too heavy on the bourbon.

Bottle courtesy of Santa. 

Pours a deep brownish black with a nice brown head. Aroma of bourbon, cherries, coffee, chocolate and dark malts. Flavor is oak, bourbon, cherry, chocolate, roasty, and quite a bit of diacetyl. There is a touch of sourness in the cherry taste but the diacetyl is overpowering many of the other flavors in this one. Still a really nice BA cherry stout.
bottle at OTR thanks to Devin.  This was probably the best beer i had at otr, maybe ever.  beer like this needs to be more available.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with deep red hints when held up to a light. Aroma is very much like a fine liquor more than a beer. Notes of sweet cherries, oak, and earth all playing nicely off of one another. Taste is wonderful... Not to heavy on any one flavor they are all placed very evenly with in the taste of this beer. Cherries, oak, and an earthy port flavor make up the taste of the beer. Mouthfeel is smooth almost creamy with a hint of alcohol burn. Excellent!

Poured a black color with a tan head. Aroma was of sweet chocolate, bourbon and sour cherries. Flavor was really interesting, a nice sweet bourbon and vanilla foretaste with a nice tart sour cherry finish. Really interesting stuff.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2011 @ home with the club. Was in a challenge up against Central Waters Bourbon Barrel Aged Cherry Stout. Pours black with a small head. Sweet with some tartness. Aromas of bourbon, wood and cherries. Very light alcohol notes. Medium to full bodied. Roasted malts ind the dry finish. This one won the challenge.

Really thick opaque black pour with a dark tan head.  Intense vanilla oak aroma - almost like an oaky glass of red wine.  Hints of bourbon and cherry as well as chocolate.  Bourbon flavor with lots of oak.  Dry with some sourness. Cherry flavor throughout with some spicy cinnamon and coconut notes.  Bitter coffee ground finish.  Alcohol hidden well, but is present.
Pours thick with almost no head. Aroma is grapes and mostly like wine. Flavor is slightly sour, and continues the "this is really wine" trend. Well balanced and very good.

Rating #1500. Bottle. Big thanks to Sparky27 for sending me this one. Poured a deep black body with thin head. Aroma is oak, vanilla and light fruit. Flavor is oak, vanilla, cherry, chocolate. Slight dry with the sweetness comming in at the end.
Her er en god øl som Bager har medbragt til ungdomsklubben. Kulsort med et karamelfarver skum. Choko, dumlekarameller, vanille, kaffe og en anelse tobak. Let kirsebær. rimelig lækker.

Bottle from mmm///beer, thanks a million.  Wow this is one unique beer. I poured this into my Gulden Draak tulip and watched the black, viscous liquid coat the glass as it poured.  I sniffed the bourbon and chocolate aroma for 5 minutes as I warmed the beer slighly in my palms.  I smelled liquid raisins and possibly a dried cherry aroma.  I watched the thin brown head stick around and watched it flow around the contours of my glass as I swirled it. The flavor hit my tongue with a bourbon flair followed by a tart, fleeting taste of cherries.  The finish is bourbon follwed by more dark, bitter chocolate.  By my palette this is a masterpiece, but I could see how some would not appreciate it.  Like fine art, some will covet it while others will sneer.  Bravo Bells. Bravo!

Bottle: Batch 7777 from the Eccentric Cafe:  Pitch black pour with a rocky, deep tan head.  Basically this comes off like a bourbon-soaked cherry covered in fine chocolate both in the nose and taste...some mild woodsy tones noted.  Amazing brew!
12oz bottle via trade with mmm///beer.  Pours like motor oil with a small, chocolate colored head.  The nose had hints of tart cherry, bourbon and oak.  One of the better brews I’ve had from Bells.

Courtesy of northernbrews
Bottle:  The aroma consists of bourbon, butterscotch, chocolate, and light tart cherries.  It pours a dark brown,virtually black, with a moderate beige head.  The flavor starts with chocolate and very faint butterscotch.  The bourbon presence is subtle.  The finish has some moderate tart cherry notes.  Much better than the regular cherry stout.  So much better, that I need to revisit the regular Cherry Stout in order to see if I like it better than my old rating.

[Batch 7777] Poured a dark brown / chestnut color with a small, tan head that left light lacing on the glass. Aroma of bourbon, vanilla, cherry, charred oak, roasted malts, and a bit of cocoa.  Taste of vanilla, roast, dark chocolate, toffee, bourbon, sweeter cherries, and a dry, oaky finish.  Another thanks to Steve for this gem!

12 oz bottle from batch 7777 courtesy of sprinkle.  Pours black with a medium sized diminishing tan head.  I found myself continuing to just revisit the aroma over and over.  Nose was black cherry, molasses, vanilla, wood, bourbon, and light chocolate.  The flavor had more cherry, molasses, chocolate, vanilla, bourbon and oak.  There was also some acidity that accompanied the alcohol especially as it warmed a bit.  This beganon the sticky full side, but thinned a little as it warmed up.  I am happy to have sampled this excellent beer.

Bottle, batch 7777.  Pours dark with a thin creamy head, no lacing.  Aroma is very cherry, almost overly so.  Also present are wood, vanilla, and bourbon.  Taste is, again, very cherry.  Cherry takes on a tart flavor, though also very sweet.  Other flavors only serve to accent the heavy cherry; those are oak, bourbon, and vanilla.  While this is a ’sweet stout’, it’s almost like a sweet stout and sour hybrid, as the finish is very tart.  Mouth is pretty creamy.  Overall, this isn’t really what I was looking for or expecting.  The cherries are over the top, and would benefit from being a little more subdued.

Much thanks to hopdog for sharing this one!  Pours a deep black with a medium creamy/bubbly tan head that left some lacing.  Aroma of vanilla, tart cherry, cherry pie, caramel, light chocolate notes, vanilla and some nuts.  Flavor of tart cherries, cherry pie, vanilla, some caramel, light chocolate notes and some tartness that lingers.  Really impressed by this beer!

Bottle.  Black color, wisps of light tan head.  Great aroma - soft vanilla and bourbon notes, sour cherry, oak.  The oak aroma isn’t too tannic and is softened by the sweeter characters.  Bourbon is more apparent on the taste - lends a nice addition to the base beer.  The sour twang of the cherry is evened out by vanilla and oak, but the end result is a rich, decadent beer.

Pours dark brown almost black w/ solid finger of creamy brown foam. Sweet aroma of dark chocolate, cream, cherry, vanilla, bourbon, oak, & treacle. Soft, creamy feel. Flavour is sweet, rich, somewhat roasty but also tart & tannic--from the cherries & oak I suppose. Finish is warm and bourbon-like (surprise). Quite nice.

Batch 7777.  Pours an oily, pitch black color with a small, quickly fleeting, mocha colored head.  A few isolated spots are all that remain after the thick, viscous legs slowly droop down the glass.  The aroma shows sweet, dark, chocolate covered cherries, a hint of lactose, and a massive wash of sour mash Kentucky bourbon.  Flavors follow suit, hot from the bourbon, with a huge, bittersweet chocolate profile and semi-sour cherries.  On the finish, sour heat coats the tongue and stays there for a good while.  The body is thick and viscous, but gets to be cloying pretty quickly, coating the mouth in sugar.  The various elements just aren’t sitting right with me.  Chocolate, sour fruit, lactose, and hot bourbon?  It just doesn’t work all that well together in my book.  If I had to sum it up in one word, I’d have to say "overkill."
Poured a dark brown with dark brown head.  Aroma was malty, and a little sweet.  Flavor is of dark malt, a little chocolate, and sweet, slightly tart cherries.  Good carbonation.  Get in my belly!!

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2008 Bottle shared at RBSG during the grand tasting held at Pizza Port Carlsbad in San Diego.

Second taste thanks to toncatcher. Excellent aromas this time in my glass. A lot more then I got at the RBSG. Awesome stuff.

Bottle shared by Blake.  Black body under a tight brown head.  Smells like maraschino cherries over toasty wood & chocolate - the "fake" cherry smell isn’t that appealing. ~RBSG ’08~

Bottle at the Grand Tasting. Pours black with a nice fluffy head, and creamy lacing. Boozy cherries right off the bat in the nose, slight tartness, some sherry. Much thanks to Zathrus13 for this one. Pours black with a slightly off white head, little reddish hues when held up to the light. Aroma is of cherry, bourbon and some roasted malt. Taste is very complex and wonderfully balanced. Tart/sweet cherries blend with roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla and bourbon. Nice creamy full mouthfeel. I need to find more of this....

Pours a luxurious black/ruby from the bottle with a hefty head of dark tan foam.  Laced with the sweetness of cherries and cream over the aroma of bourbon and cherries.  Tart on the finish, but a definite treat.

Thanks to Sepiroth for the bottle.  Pours a thicker than expected dark brown with good sized tan head that foamed over after the pour.   Nose of cherry tang, acidic bourbony notes, slight hints of chocolate, as well as toasted/roasted malts and of course vanilla cherry.  Flavor is similar with the vanilla cherry chocolate bourbon punch coming through pretty strong.  Overall very descent beer,like an aged Cherry Stout(my absolute favorite  aged beer so far) with a kick of bourbon.

Thanks to JayMFG for the taste. Pours black with a thick tan head. Aroma is cherrys,vanilla, bourbon, and sweet white cake icing. Taste has more cherry, bourbon, sweet malt and roasted grains. Finishes a little cherry sweet. Really enjoyed this one.

Thanks to Linus_Stick for this one!
Pours dark brown with a small beige head. At room temp, "the horror. the horror" fades a little more, and the taste actually becomes coordinated,  though the aftertaste is still painful. Later on in the finish the cherries turn a bit "artificial".  Overall, I rather enjoyed this, but couldn’t handle too much at one sitting.

The aroma was spot on to what I expected: cherry...check, bourbon barrel...check, chocolate...check, toasty...check, and earthy yeast...check. VERY NICE NOSE! The mouth feel is lush and oily but a tad too soft by the end. A very nice hybrid beer.

12oz bottle shared thanks to thickerfreakness.  pours dark with a brown head.  Nose is of black cherries and oak.  Taste is of cherries and some bourbon.  Mouthfeel is medium with carbonation and some tartness from the cherries and a hint of alcohol.

Bottle sampled at sliffy’s and again at mgumby10’s - thanks guys:  The aroma of this beer reminds me of cartoons, where there is a pie in the window and the tantalizing, animated steam coming off of that pie wafts into the nose of an unsuspecting passerby and it blissfully lifts him off of the ground and he floats, salivating, through the air toward said pie in the anticipation that the olfactory deliciousness of the aroma could hope to match the taste of it.  That kind of sums up this beer for me.  If you could capture the aroma of this beer into an extract, it would be the best-selling candle at Bob Evans.  Tart and sweet cherry pie filling, perfectly spiced with just the right amount of warm vanilla wafts on top of lightly bourbon-soaked oak.  It smells at first like pie, then like icing.  The flavor is just as complex, with dark malts swirling with vanilla, tart cherry, and light bourbon.  Dry character.  A very interesting blend that far surpasses the plain Cherry Stout.

text: tasted with the phoenix crew. batch 7777 bottles opened by sparky27. pours near black with a medium shade of brown head. light lacing is present as it retreats. aroma is really cheesy... barrel woodiness, spice, dark grain, vanilla, cherry skin and a touch of alcohol warmth. the flavor is fruity but not necessarily cherry at first... it is more like a gigantic tannic structure. as time goes on and dave gets sillier it develops into red cherries, cinnamon, caramel,  barrel dry goodness, chocolate and some mild bourbon. nice and tart. medium to full body... tartness keeps it mellow. smooth mouth feel. this was quite impressive considering that i really didn’t like the regular version...

From a 12oz Bottle, Batch #7777.  Bottle courtesy of CharlesDarwin.  Dark black, chalky opaque colored pour, edged in ruby, topped with a creamy finger of tan foam.  A butterscotch diacetyl aroma jumps out in the nose right away, but after the initial negative impression, it starts to fade into the background.  Doughy, pretzely bourbon notes accompany tart black cherry skins and some dry dark chocolate.  Lots of cherry in the nose, along with some harsher higher alcohols.  Medium full bodied, creamy carbonated mouthfeel with a slick, velvety texture.  The diacteyl, while still present, seems to be much more restrained in the flavors, leading to a more enjoyable drinking experience.  Rich mid-malt flavors of toffee and caramel up front on the palate, along with some lighter vanilla barrel notes.  Chewy fudge and hints of plum come out mid-palate.  The cherry comes out strong on the back end, along with bourbon soaked caramel flavors.  The combination of bourbon and cherry seemed a little strange to my palate at first, but I really warmed up to the flavor combination as I sipped this beer.  Both bold traits seem to be well balanced and work well together.  Unfortunately for me, the diacetyl was a major detractor, but I would imagine another clean batch of this would be simply stellar.  It seems very uncharacteristic of Bells (at least in my tasting experience) to sell a beer with an obvious flaw, especially one that was likely present before the beer even went into the barrel.  Nonetheless, I really hope this beer gets brewed again, as I can imagine batch 2 being a real treat.  Thanks a ton, Tom!

Courtesy JMFG.  Pours black, with a small light brown head.  Smells of thick, rich vanilla, dark roasty malts, light cherry notes, and bourbon.  The flavor is remarkably balanced. The bourbon definitely helps this brew out considering I think the Cherry Stout is decent not great.  This combo seemed to work.  I enjoyed the blend in flavors.

Aroma is chocolate covered cherry, vanilla, and light charred oak and bourbon.  Flavor is more chocolate covered cherry, vanilla and light roast, with a nice lingering tartness mingled with a subtle oaky bourbon finish.  This sure worked for me, and found the bourbon barrel to compliment well.  Thanks again Chad!

Pours dark brown, with a brown head. Aroma is bourbon, cherries, chocolate, and vanilla.  Flavor is bourbon, cherries, chocolate, malt, vanilla and alcohol. Im liking this one, but it is still a little hot and kind of in your face. Thanks to cpferris for this bottle.

Bottle shared by Pud, thanks Dave.   Pours nearly black with the slightest of red tones, tan colored head.   Aroma is oak, bourbon, vanilla, almond, tart cherries, the nose is the only redeeming characteristic.   Flavor is ALL bourbon, slightest hint of roast, light oak, I really gotta work hard to find the cherries.   Palate is full bodied, light carbonation, finished HOT, really HOT!   I found this to be quite horrid.   I cant understand all the high ratings for something so horribly unbalanced.   The original beer, the cherry stout, is not even distinguishable in this offering.   Total miss, nearly undrinkable as it warms.   I hate to totally slam a beer graciouosly shared by a friend, but this SUCKED!   Cant wait til Moejuck get hold of this one!

Pours a wicked dark reddish-brown with a small tan head that struggles for survival.  The cherry cordial aroma found in Bells standard Cherry Stout is made more complex by the sweet bourbon and woody notes.  Phenomenally tasty - the flavor is much more complex and integrated than that of the off-the-shelf Cherry Stout.  Bourbon flavors become more pronounced as it warms up.  Most of the shortcomings of the standard CS are improved by barrel aging, but still could stand a little bit more body.

Bottle shared by Crosling.  Poured a deep ruby-brown color with a thin beige head that diminished to a ring.  Aroma of charred oak, bourbon, chocolate malt, and some moderately tart cherries.  Lightly tart cherry entry leads into a smooth chocolate flavor with a moderate oak presence moving into a light bourbon finish with a light tart cherry flavor in the finish.  Smooth with a nice oak bite and acidity from the cherries.  Sweet, thanks for sharing Nick.

Very complex nose, with caramel, cocoa, tiramisu, bourbon soaked wood and cherry.    Dark brown color with a light tan head, just like regular cherry stout.  Flavors are well intergrated, dominated by chocolate and cherry juice notes, but also some vanilla, fudge  Only a light hint of the barrel.  Thin body, which is somewhat disappointing.  Overall, pretty happy with it and looking forward to seeing it progress.

Pours black with a reddish tan head that clings to the rim of the glass. Aroma is cherries, oak, vanilla, and whiskey. Much of the stout notes are lost in the flavor, leaving a cherry bourbon taste. The roastiness of the stout emerges and the flavors begin to mesh better as it warms. Im not convinced the bourbon barrel aging adds to the beer, but it doesnt make it worse.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2008 Bottle, batch #7777.  Black pour with a brown head that fades quickly.  Aroma is lots of bourbon with notes of chocolate, coffee, vanilla, and subtle tart cherries.  Sweet blend of cherry, vanilla and bourbon in the flavor with a touch of butterscotch, chocolate,coffee and a slight vinous note in the finish.  Oily full body with lots of carbonation and a bit astringent.  Rich, a little cloying and the carbonation is a little too much but still delicious.

Batch #7777, bottle. Opaque deep brown-black body, oily, thin brown head. Buttery oak nose, tart, with cherry and roasted malts, but primarily barrel. Bourbony oak body, more bourbon than I picked up in the nose, soaking the roasted malts and not subtle but not strong tart cherry notes. Just a touch of roasty dryness in the finish. A rich slow sipper.

Batch 7777 bottle.  Pours very dark brown with only the faintest bit of light showing at the bottom of the glass.  huge and heavy nose of buttered oak, with the bourbon notes somewhat hidden or just plain light overall.  Sugary sweet butter and brie, with a small note of black cherries.  Sharp and rich on the palate, buttered bourbon is heavy, overall the beer is coarse and somewhat dry and rough.  Tannic almond/amaretto and stinky cheese/butter in the finish.  Interesting.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2008 12oz bottle, batch #7777, courtesy of SQNfan and artusory.  Thanks, guys!  Pours a very dark, dense chocolate-cola color; fluffy medium-dark brown head with web-like lacing.  Chocolate-covered cherries and strongly toasted and vanilla-laden oak character (like a heavily oaked chardonnay) in the aroma; some sweet butteriness, with dark chocolate and ripe cherries lurking beneath.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: chewy, intense chocolate cherries, roasted malts, buttery bourbon, and solid chocolate presence; very generous, clearly expressed barrel character melded well with a beer I normally dont care for; just enough cherry coming through to make this an especially interesting beer; really great stuff, and the barrel character works nicely here.  Damn tasty.  Lengthy finish: dark chocolate, fudge, and some lingering red fruits at the far end; decadent.

Big thanks to Anwar for this bottle!
I dont know what it is, but Larry has a knack for picking the right barrels and amount of time for his beers.  This along with the BA Expo/DC, BA Java, BA Third Coast are all exceptionally done.
The balance between bourbon and cherry is perfect.  Only on a few sips did the bourbon dominate.  Mostly they were neck and neck fighting for the forefront.  Delicious mouthfeel.  Very good BA undertones.  The oak, vanilla everything melds well together with the cherry.  Good mouthfeel.
Im still waiting on the straight BA Expedition!  Bottle some of that for a brotha!

UPDATED: APR 7, 2009 12oz bottle from derek.....i wasnt expecting much from this brew considering the fact that i was not particularly found of their cherry stout but damn!.....very close to lack pour with brown edges that left a thin swirling medium tan head.....a very nice plethora of aromas make up the nose: bourbon, soft vanilla, toggee, molasses, and a dash of sour cherries which were all nicely melded together.....for the sake of trying not to be redundant, the flavors were a solid combination of the aforementioned qualites found in the nose.  the barrel aging really worked well with this beer and genuinely enhanced the beer.

One of the most unique aromas I have encountered in a long time. BBA roasted coffee grounds,distinct oak, and a butterscotch ,caramel finish. This defintely smells more like warm bakery then beer. Cherry not that evident. Chocolate and rich malts,with more roastedness and now some cherry in flavor,smooth and creamy,slight detraction is a little acrid bitter finish,like you would get from old coffee,plus I was never a fan of whatever Bells is using to get that cherry flavor,but I quibble. Absolutely remarkable in its complexity and barrel flavors. Thanks Kingpin

Pours out rich and dark with a deep carmel head that dissapates quickely. The aroma is startling and overwhelming. Odd and fantastic at the same time. It smells like an inky cabernet.
You get chocolate , cherry, vanilla, charred oak, and oh yeah you get the bourbon aspect as well. Its funky, yet... one sip and you know you want more. It coats the mouth with thick cocoa, subtle tart black cherry, and the alcohol . Its not hidden. well done but my guess was 8.5abv. and hey, It is what it is. Yummy...If they ever sell this one in the market its gonna be a winner.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2008 Bottle pours pitch black with a nice tan head.  Has a dark fruit aroma with some cherry in there somewhere.  There is also some bourbon on the nose.  Has a medium to heavy mouthfeel.  Taste is oak, vanilla, bourbon, vanilla, cherry, vanilla, and finishes with a slight cherry tart flavor that merries all the flavors together beautifully .  This is a great beer.

12oz bottle (thanks Derek!!!). Poured a dark black with brown edges and an averaged sized brown head. Aromas of wood/oak, vanilla, the cherries were present but not overpowering, some bourbon, and light smoke. Tastes of cherries (starts out sweet and ends lightly tart), vanilla, oak, bourbon, some roastiness, and light chocolate. Creamy body with the alcohol well hidden. Cherry burps. I found neither the cherries or bourbon was over done and worked well together. I had this one after dinner and it made a great dessert.

I am not a huge fan of the normal cherry stout or fruit stouts in general, so I wondered how this one would fair.  Aroma was a rich vanilla bourbon with a hint of cherries.  Taste was much the same, great velvety mouthfeel, big and rich vanilla cream, with a balancing cherry tartness and some roast as well.  I actually liked the amount of bourbon in this one.  Almost vinous at times.  I think my only problems are more with the fact that this is a fruit stout, but overall, this was great.

12oz  Bottle. Noses a strong currant-tinted bourbon. Light roast backs up a warm alcohol sensation. Well blended and melded. Dappled with middle red fruits, pluots and cranberry. Not overly complex, but a little cold. Pours a rim in tan, with a deep black-mahogany and a brown rim. Palate starts out really oaky and dry, but then gracefully slides into a strong Mexican vanilla flan, custard and cream. Sweet, but not too much. A touch too barreled for me, but not bad. Im not drawing a ton of the beer base through some of the bourbon, but its expression is pretty decent. Vinous, some aged sherry and wine character. A touch curt as you keep drinking. Finish is impressive. Long, tart fruity. Complex. Just awesome as it develops. Really intricate and layered. Lots of different flavor. Excellent use of a barrel. Finishes forever in roast, cherry juice, bourbon and candy. Delightful! Thanks Sean!

On tap at the 2007 GTMW: Pours an opaque black with a frothy, well-lacing dark tan head.  Aroma of oaky vanilla bourbon and tart cherries.  Body is semi-sweet, smooth and dark caramel and chocolate malty with nice cherry balance and fruity notes.  Well done and enjoyable.

Tap at Slows in Detroit: Super dark with tan head and gobs of spotty ;acing.  The aroma is a great combo of sweet bourbon along with the cherry.  You can definitely taste the alcohol and the tangy cherries.  The aftertaste is wonderful.  This is something you might want to sip over the course of a long movie.  Yum.

Tap @ GTMW 2007. Opaque and black with a lasting, thinning tan head. Aroma is alive with sinuous and decadent blackberries, cherries, raspberries, bourbon laced chocolate and truffles. Flavor dances with tart cherries and a hint of black cherries. The chocolate manifests in a tart, lactic order that cures palatary lust. Tart, balanced and altruistic, with red raspberry kernels melting into raspberry java juice. Soft, subtle carbonation accentuates the supple slick body while cherry talc slips through a sleek palate remembrance. Black raspberries and cocoa planted black cherries finish out the show.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2007 GTMW. Bourbon Barrel Cherry Stout. Poured from a mannequin dressed as Waldo. The odd thing about this beer was that Im not particularly fond of the non barrel aged cherry stout, but I happened to be near the Bells tent when this was being poured, and so who can resist a sample. Im glad I gave into temptation. Nose is bourbon and imperial stout, with a hint of fruit. Palate was thick and chewy, with flavors of malted milk balls, sour cherry, French roast, and a slight sweetness on the finish. It seems as though the components I didnt like about the cherry stout were much more rounded out and balanced here. Perhaps both the aging process and the bourbon together resulted in this being a fabulous beer.

Something I had in the middle of the Indiana Brewers Guild fest.  Dark Dark brown with a thin tan head.  Nary a sign of cherry initially. There is a big healthy bourbon stout nose though.  Sweet alcohol nose over a slightly cherry to oaky nose.  As this warms, the cherry comes out.  Thin body without much fizz of body, but this only makes this more drinkable, not watery.  Cherry obviates itself with warming.  Bourbon stout up front when cold though.  Roast, alcohol, and cherry beats out the sweetness, driving the balance out, but this isnt a bad thing in my opinion.  My only concern is that bourbon barrel aged cherry stout is something different than the oak aged cherry stout...

Sample at Indiana Microbrewers Festival - Aroma of roasted dark malts, oak, vanilla and subtle dark cherry.  Pours black with a small head.  Flavor matches aroma with the cherry tartness taking over the aftertaste.  Palate is sticky and tart.  Very nice.

Pours well with a thin dark brown head.  It smells of roasted coffee and dark cherries.  The it feels slightly oily when sipped but fills the mouth with a warm lasting glow.  It tastes of coffee and slightly bitter cherries and is slightly sweet.  This is a good after dinner beer, or perhaps one to drink while eating a salad.

GTMW 06, great big Larry Bell pour. Black body with no head. The aroma is bourbon, cherry, chocolate, coffee and roast. The flavor is cherry, molases and toffee, semi-sweet. Full, sticky body with a soft texture.

Poured by Larry @ Taste of the Midwest.  poured a cloudy poo brown color w/ a tiny whisp of head.  Aromas of slightly tart cherries burnt carmels and light chocolates.  Palate was well coated and lightly creamy.   Flavor was mostly the tart cherry a bit of an odd taste w/ it the cherries ahve just never tasted right to me in this beer.  Some light boozy bourbon notes emerge w/ warmth and lots of sweet malts and hints of wood.
2006 GTMW. Thanks Larry! Clear dark brown, no head. Cherry roasted brown sugar. Solidy smooth cherry melded with bourbon. Chocolate. Simply put, a perfect cherry stout.

On tap at the Great Taste of the Midwest, poured by Mr. Bell himself!  Poured a deep, murky brown with a dusting of caramel head.  Nose was of strong, tart cherries with dark chocolate and solid accents from the bourbon barrel (bourbon sweetness, oak, and vanilla).  Flavor consisted primarily of tart cherries, oak, vanilla, and dark chocolates... more oak and bourbon accents emerge with time.  The palate was a tad too slick and light with the bourbon... also a tad grainy.  Sticky, malty, vanilla-ey finish.  Solid brew!
